facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 1108 and 1109 of 1963 are appeals by special leave from the judgment and order dated March 15, 1962 of the Allahabad High Court in Special Appeal No. 574 of 1960.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 1108 and 1109 of 1963. Appeals by special leave from the judgment and order, dated March, 15, 1962 of the Allahabad High Court in Special Appeal No. 574 of 1960 and Supreme Court Appeal No. 53 of 1962 respectively.

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 1108 of 1963 is against a judgment of the Allahabad High Court dated March 15, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 1108 of 1963 is against a judgment of the Allahabad High Court, dated March 15, 1962 and Civil Appeal No. 1109 of 1963 is against an order of the same High Court, dated May 9, 1962 declining to certify the case under Art. 133 of the Constitution as in the opinion of the High Court the proceedings from which the appeal arose before the High Court was number a civil proceeding within Art. 133.

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 1109 of 1963 is against an order of the Allahabad High Court dated May 9, 1962 declining to certify under Art. 133.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 1109 of 1963 is against an order of the same High Court, dated May 9, 1962 declining to certify the case under Art. 133 of the Constitution as in the opinion of the High Court the proceedings from which the appeal arose before the High Court was number a civil proceeding within Art. 133.

facts.text: Kays Construction Co. Pvt Ltd. is the appellant in both appeals.

anchor.surface_text: As special leave has been granted against the judgment of the High Court and we are of opinion that the appeal against that judgment must be dismissed, we do number think it necessary to decide the other appeal.

facts.text: The appellant Company is the successor of a private concern named Kays Construction Company owned by Mr. H. M. Khosla who is Managing Director of the appellant Company.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant Company is the successor of a private companycern which went under the name of Kays Construction Company and was owned by one Mr. H. M. Khosla who is number Managing Director of the appellant Company.

facts.text: Mr. Khosla found it unprofitable to continue the business as his own and stopped it for a while before Kays Construction Co. Private Ltd. came into existence.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that Mr. Khosla found it unprofitable to companytinue the business as his own and he stopped it for a while before Kays Construction Co.  Private  Ltd. came into existence.

facts.text: The appellant Company took over the business and some of the workmen of the former company but not all.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant Company took over the business and with it, some of the workmen of the former companycern but number all.

facts.text: This led to an Industrial dispute before the Allahabad Industrial Tribunal Sugar and an award was made on January 31, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: This led to an Industrial dispute before the Allahabad Industrial Tribunal  Sugar  and an award was made on January 31, 1958.

facts.text: One of the questions in dispute before the Tribunal was the reinstatement and back wages of the workmen who were not re-employed by the appellant Company.

anchor.surface_text: One of the questions in dispute before the Tribunal was the reinstatement and back wages of the workmen who were number re- employed by the appellant Company.

facts.text: The Tribunal held that management of Kays Construction Co. Private Limited, Allahabad, are required to reinstate the old workmen given in the Annexure of Kays Construction Co., Allahabad, restore them in old or equivalent jobs with continuity of service, and pay 50% of back wages.

anchor.surface_text: As a result of my findings above, I hold that management of Messrs. Kays Construction Co.  Private  Limited, Allahabad, are required to reinstate the old workmen given in the Annexure of Messrs. Kays Construction Co., Allahabad. They will be restored in their old or equivalent jobs and given companytinuity of service. In view of the somewhat peculiar features of this case and in the largest interest of the Industry, I would, however, order that the workmen be paid only 50 per cent, of their back wages for the period they were forcibly kept out of employment.

facts.text: After the award, a large number of workmen preferred claims for back wages under s.6-H(1) of U.P. Industrial Disputes Act, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: After this award a large number of the workmen preferred claims for their back wages purporting to do so under the first sub.section of s. 6-H of the U.P. Industrial Disputes Act, 1947.

facts.text: Appellant Company made objections to the demand before the Labour Commissioner, U.P.: some workmen accepted employment with appellant or elsewhere, some not parties to original dispute or died, exact days not determined.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant Company made a large number of objections to this demand before the Labour Commissioner, U.P. to whom the powers of the State Government under the first sub-section of S. 6-H had been delegated. These objections, briefly stated, were that some of the workmen had already accepted employment either with the appellant Company or elsewhere and that some of them were either number parties to the original dispute or had died subsequent to the award. The appellant Company also companytended that as the exact number of days for which different workmen had been forcibly kept out of employment was number determined an order under S. 6-H 1  companyld number be passed.

facts.text: Labour Commissioner issued certificate to Collector, Allahabad on July 21, 1958 for Rs. 1,06,588-6-6.

anchor.surface_text: On July 21, 1958 the Labour Commissioner, purporting to act under the first sub-section of s. 6-H issued a certificate to the Collector, Allahabad for the recovery of Rs. 1,06,588-6-6.

facts.text: Regional Conciliation Officer, Allahabad ordered to verify claims after objections to State Government.

anchor.surface_text: Certain objections having been filed by the appellant Company before the State Government, the Regional Conciliation Officer, Allahabad was ordered to verify the claims.

facts.text: Labour Commissioner issued another certificate on September 9, 1959 reducing sum to Rs. 50,654-9-6.

anchor.surface_text: In the meantime, the Labour Commissioner issued another certificate on September 9, 1959 by which the sum to be recovered was reduced to Rs. 50,654-9-6.

facts.text: Collector passed order on September 10, 1959 demanding sum from security deposited by appellant with Chief Mechanical Engineer, North-East Railway, Gorakhpur.

anchor.surface_text: On September 10, 1959, the Collector passed an order which was companymunicated telegraphically to the Chief Mechanical Engineer, North-East Railway, Gorukhpur demanding the said sum for payment to the workmen, from the security deposited by the appellant Company with the Chief Mechanical Engineer.

facts.text: Appellant filed petition under Art. 226 on November 2, 1959 to quash orders dated September 9 and 10, 1959 and release property under attachment.

anchor.surface_text: On November 2, 1959 the appellant Company filed a petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution to have the orders dated September 9 and 10, 1959 quashed by a writ of certiorari or by any other suitable order or direction and for release of some property which, it may be mentioned, was under attachment after the first certificate was issued.

facts.text: Mr. Justice Broome allowed the petition, quashed orders and attachment on condition of security.

anchor.surface_text: The petition was heard by Mr. Justice Broome of the Allahabad High Court and was allowed by him. He quashed the two orders of the Labour Commissioner and the attachment of the property on companydition that the Company furnished adequate security to the satisfaction of the District Magistrate of Allahabad.

facts.text: Broome J. held that claims should be under s.6-H(2) before Labour Court as exact amount to be determined.

anchor.surface_text: The only question that was companysidered was whether the claim of the workmen before the Labour Commissioner fell to be companysidered under the first or the second sub-section of s. 6-H. Mr. Justice Broome relying upon the analogy of M. S. S. Transports... held that as the exact amount was required to be determined, proceedings had to be taken before the Labour Court under the second sub-section...

facts.text: Division Bench reversed Broome J. by order dated March 15, 1962, held under s.6-H(1).

anchor.surface_text: Against this decision an appeal was filed under the Letters Patent of the High Court and by the order, number under appeal, the judgment of Broome J. was reversed.

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal against the High Court judgment.

anchor.surface_text: As special leave has been granted against the judgment of the High Court and we are of opinion that the appeal against that judgment must be dismissed, we do number think it necessary to decide the other appeal.

facts.text: Division Bench held that back wages is money due under s.6-H(1), not benefit under s.6-H(2).

anchor.surface_text: The Division Bench held that the words of the second sub-section any benefit which is capable of being companyputed in terms of money indicated benefits like free quarters or free electricity and number something which a workman earned through his labour.

facts.text: Supreme Court agreed with Division Bench that back wages fall under s.6-H(1).

anchor.surface_text: In our judgment, a case such as the present, where the money due is back wages for the period of unemployment is companyered by the first sub-section and number the second.

facts.text: Property was under attachment after first certificate.

anchor.surface_text: for release of some property which, it may be mentioned, was under attachment after the first certificate was issued.

facts.text: Appellant had security deposited with Chief Mechanical Engineer, North-East Railway, Gorakhpur.

anchor.surface_text: from the security deposited by the appellant Company with the Chief Mechanical Engineer.

anchor.surface_text: After this award a large number of the workmen preferred claims for their back wages purporting to do so under the first sub.section of s. 6-H of the U.P. Industrial Disputes Act, 1947.

concepts.unlisted_description: Recovery of money due from employer under award or settlement

anchor.surface_text: That section, shorn of provisions which do number companycern us, reads as follows - 6-H 1  Where any money is due to the workmen from an employer under the provisions of Section 6-H to 6-R under a settlement or award, or under an award given by an adjudicator or the State Industrial Tribunal appointed or companystituted under this Act, before the companymencement of the Uttar Pradesh Industrial Disputes  Amendment and Miscellaneous Provisions  Act, 1956, the workman may, without prejudice to any other mode of recovery, make an application to the State Government for the recovery of the money due to him, and if the State Government is satisfied that any money is so due, it shall issue a certificate for the amount to the companylector who shall proceed to recover the same as if it were an arrear of land revenue. Where any workman is entitled to receive from the employer any benefit which is capable of being companyputed in terms of money, the amount at which such benefit should be companyputed may subject to any rule that may be made under this Act be determined by such Labour Court as may be specified in this behalf by the State Government, and the amount so determined may be recovered as provided for in subsection  1 .  3

concepts.unlisted_description: Recovery of money due from employer under award or settlement

anchor.surface_text: The question thus is how are the two sub- sections to be read ? This section is analogous to s. 33C of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947 and s. 20 of the Industrial Disputes  Appellate Tribunal  Act, 1950, It is significant that in all the three statutes the companynate section is divided into two parts and the first part deals with recovery of money due to a workman under an award and the second deals with a benefit companyputable in terms of money.

concepts.interpretation: Sub-section (1) covers money due like back wages involving arithmetical calculation; sub-section (2) covers benefits not money due but computable in money terms like free quarters, requiring determination by Labour Court.
concepts.unlisted_description: Recovery of money due from employer under award or settlement

arguments.claim: Order under s.6-H(1) cannot be passed as exact number of days for which workmen kept out of employment not determined

anchor.surface_text: The appellant Company also contended that as the exact number of days for which different workmen had been forcibly kept out of employment was not determined an order under S. 6-H 1 could not be passed.

arguments.court_reasoning: Mere arithmetical calculations of amount due covered by first sub-section; verification for State Government satisfaction under s.6-H(1)

arguments.claim: Some workmen accepted employment with appellant or elsewhere, some not parties to dispute or died, so money not due

anchor.surface_text: These objections, briefly stated, were that some of the workmen had already accepted employment either with the appellant Company or elsewhere and that some of them were either not parties to the original dispute or had died subsequent to the award.

arguments.claim: Claims fall under s.6-H(2) not (1) as exact amount required to be determined by Labour Court

anchor.surface_text: The only question that was considered was whether the claim of the workmen before the Labour Commissioner fell to be considered under the first or the second sub-section of s. 6-H. Mr. Justice Broome relying upon the analogy of M. S. S. Transports

court_response_anchor.surface_text: the first or the second sub-section of s. 6-H. Mr. Justice Broome relying upon the analogy of M. S. S. Transports, Tiruchirapalli v. Rajaram and Anoth

arguments.court_reasoning: Reversed by Division Bench; affirmed by Supreme Court that back wages is money due under s.6-H(1)

arguments.claim: s.6-H(2) 'any benefit capable of being computed in terms of money' means perquisites like free quarters not wages earned by labour

anchor.surface_text: The Division Bench held that the words of the second sub-section any benefit which is capable of being computed in terms of money indicated benefits like free quarters or free electricity and not something which a workman earned through his labour.

arguments.court_reasoning: Supreme Court agrees: contrast between money due and benefit computable distinguishes sub-sections

arguments.claim: Computation of benefit in terms of money different from arithmetical calculation of back wages; relies on S.S. Shetty v. Bharat Nidhi

anchor.surface_text: Reliance was placed upon a decision of this Court in S. S. Shetty v. Bharat Nidhi Ltd. where Bhagwati J. has pointed out that if any benefit awarded by the Tribunal was not expressed in terms of money it was necessary to have it computed

arguments.court_reasoning: Supreme Court adopts similar scheme interpretation

arguments.claim: Distinguishes Kasturi Sons as s.17 expressly refers to money due like wages; Punjab National Bank as monetary profit not necessarily outside benefit but context differs

anchor.surface_text: The Divisional Bench distinguished Kasturi Sons P Ltd. v. N. Salivatesaram Anr. on the ground that s. 17 of the Working Journalists Conditions of Service Miscellaneous Provisions Act, 1955 referred expressly to money due by way of compensation

arguments.claim: Does not follow High Court rulings in MSS Transports, Sesamusa Sugar, Amarsinghji Mills

anchor.surface_text: In view of these cases the Division Bench did not follow the two rulings of the High Courts cited earlier and another reported in Shri Amarsinghji Mills Ltd. v. Nagarashua M.P. Ors.

arguments.court_reasoning: Supreme Court independently reaches same conclusion without relying on those

arguments.claim: Judgment of Division Bench erroneous in interpretation of s.6-H(1) and (2)
arguments.court_reasoning: Supreme Court holds Division Bench correct: back wages covered by s.6-H(1)

arguments.claim: s.6-H analogous to s.33C ID Act and s.20 IDAT Act; scheme divides into money due under (1) and benefit computable under (2)
Back wages for unemployment period is money due covered by s.6-H(1) not (2)
Mere arithmetical calculation of back wages not requiring elaborate procedure of s.6-H(2); objections are for satisfaction under (1)

holdings.text: A case such as the present, where the money due is back wages for the period of unemployment is covered by the first sub-section of s.6-H and not the second.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Back wages constitute 'money due' under award; distinguished from 'benefit computable in money' requiring Labour Court determination; involves only arithmetical calculation for State Government satisfaction.

holdings.text: The section is divided into two parts: first deals with recovery of money due under an award (s.6-H(1)); second with benefit computable in terms of money (s.6-H(2)).
holdings.reasoning_summary: Analogous scheme in s.33C Industrial Disputes Act and s.20 Industrial Disputes Appellate Tribunal Act confirms division between money due (simple recovery) and benefits needing computation.

holdings.text: Contrast between 'money due' (s.6-H(1)) and 'benefit which is not money due but computable in money terms' (s.6-H(2)) demarcates scope of sub-sections; examples include free quarters.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual contrast and purposive reading prevent overlap; sub-s(1) retains role for simple calculations if sub-s(2) covered them.

holdings.text: Mere arithmetical calculations of amount due (like back wages) not covered by elaborate procedure of s.6-H(2).
holdings.reasoning_summary: Sub-s(2) for complex reckoning of non-monetary benefits; sub-s(1) for direct money due despite simple math needed.

holdings.text: Verification of claims and objections (e.g., employment status, days out) is for State Government satisfaction under s.6-H(1), not Labour Court determination under s.6-H(2).
holdings.reasoning_summary: Inquiry verifies quantum of existing money due, not values new benefit; aligns with sub-s(1) satisfaction clause.

holdings.text: Judgment of Division Bench correct; appeal against it dismissed.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Affirmation based on correct interpretation of s.6-H sub-sections applied to facts.

holdings.text: No need to decide Civil Appeal No. 1109 of 1963 as appeal against High Court judgment (No. 1108) dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: As special leave has been granted against the judgment of the High Court and we are of opinion that the appeal against that judgment must be dismissed, we do not think it necessary to decide the other appeal. The facts of the case may not be stated briefly.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Procedural: resolution of primary appeal renders secondary unnecessary.

precedents.citation: M. S. S. Transports, Tiruchirapalli v. Rajaram and Another 1

anchor.surface_text: M. S. S. Transports, Tiruchirapalli v. Rajaram and Another 1  decided under s. 33-C of the Industrial Disputes Act and Sesamusa Sugar Works Ltd. v. State of Bihar and Others  2   decided under s. 20 of the Industrial Disputes  Appellate Tribunal  Act, 1950, held that as the exact amount was required to be determined, proceedings had to be taken before the Labour Court under the second sub-section to determine the money equivalent of the benefit to which the workmen were entitled before the certificate companyld issue.

precedents.cited_proposition: exact amount required to be determined under second sub-section equivalent before certificate under s. 33C

precedents.citation: Sesamusa Sugar Works Ltd. v. State of Bihar and Others 2

anchor.surface_text: Sesamusa Sugar Works Ltd. v. State of Bihar and Others  2   decided under s. 20 of the Industrial Disputes  Appellate Tribunal  Act, 1950, held that as the exact amount was required to be determined, proceedings had to be taken before the Labour Court under the second sub-section to determine the money equivalent of the benefit to which the workmen were  1  1960 1 L.L.J. 336. Sup./65-2 A.I.R. 1955 Patna 49. entitled before the certificate companyld issue. In other words, Broome J.was opinion that the application of the first sub-section of s. 6-H was premature and thus erroneous.

precedents.case_name: Sesamusa Sugar Works Ltd v State of Bihar
precedents.cited_proposition: exact amount required to be determined under second sub-section equivalent before certificate under s. 20 IDAT Act

precedents.citation: S. S. Shetty v. Bharat Nidhi Ltd.

anchor.surface_text: S. S. Shetty v. Bharat Nidhi Ltd.   where Bhagwati J. has pointed out that if any benefit awarded by the Tribunal was number expressed in terms of money it was necessary to have it companyputed in terms of money before the appropriate Government companyld be asked to help in the recovery under s. 20 2  of the Industrial Disputes  Appellate Tribunal  Act 1950. In the opinion of the Division Bench this decision supported their companyclusion that the companyputation in terms of money of a benefit was something different from mere arithmetical calculation of the amount of back wages.

precedents.case_name: SS Shetty v Bharat Nidhi Ltd
precedents.cited_proposition: if benefit awarded by Tribunal not expressed in terms of money, must compute it in terms of money before recovery under s.20
precedents.cited_holding: if any benefit awarded by the Tribunal was not expressed in terms of money it was necessary to have it computed in terms of money before the appropriate Government could be asked to help in the recovery under s. 20

precedents.citation: Kasturi Sons P Ltd. v. N. Salivatesaram Anr. 2

anchor.surface_text: Kasturi Sons  P  Ltd. v. N. Salivatesaram Anr.  2  on the ground that s. 17 of the Working Journalists  Conditions of Service Miscellaneous Provisions  Act, 1955 referred expressly to money due by way of companypensation, gratuity and wages. The case in Punjab National Bank Ltd. v. Kharbunda 3  where it was held that monetary advantage or profit was number necessarily outside the word benefit as used in s. 33C of the Industrial Disputes Act 1947, was also distinguished.

precedents.case_name: Kasturi Sons Pvt Ltd v N Salivatesaram
precedents.cited_proposition: interpretation of provision referring expressly to wages and compensation

precedents.citation: Punjab National Bank Ltd. v. Kharbunda 3

anchor.surface_text: Punjab National Bank Ltd. v. Kharbunda 3  where it was held that monetary advantage or profit was number necessarily outside the word benefit as used in s. 33C of the Industrial Disputes Act 1947, was also distinguished. In view of these cases the Division Bench did number follow the two rulings of the High Courts cited earlier and another reported in Shri Amarsinghji Mills Ltd. v. Nagarashua  M.P.  Ors.4 . It is companytended before us that the judgment of the Divisional Bench is erroneous in its interpretation of s. 6- H 1  and  2 .

precedents.case_name: Punjab National Bank Ltd v Kharbunda
precedents.cited_proposition: monetary advantage or profit not necessarily outside word 'benefit' in s.33C
precedents.cited_holding: monetary advantage or profit was not necessarily outside the word benefit as used in s.33C of the Industrial Disputes Act 1947

precedents.citation: Shri Amarsinghji Mills Ltd. v. Nagarashua M.P. Ors.4

anchor.surface_text: Shri Amarsinghji Mills Ltd. v. Nagarashua  M.P.  Ors.4 . It is companytended before us that the judgment of the Divisional Bench is erroneous in its interpretation of s. 6- H 1  and  2 . The question thus is how are the two sub- sections to be read ? This section is analogous to s. 33C of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947 and s. 20 of the Industrial Disputes  Appellate Tribunal  Act, 1950, It is significant that in all the three statutes the companynate section is divided into two parts and the first part deals with recovery of money due to a workman under an award and the second deals with a benefit companyputable in terms of money.

precedents.case_name: Shri Amarsinghji Mills Ltd v Nagarashua
precedents.cited_proposition: ruling of High Court on analogous provision not followed

anchor.surface_text: The appeal fails and will be dismissed with costs.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal against the judgment of the Division Bench of Allahabad High Court dismissed; judgment upheld.
